7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Alexandria Adams Station continuously attempts to improve the safety of our processes to protect the employees, the public, and the environment.  The City of Alexandria Adams Station incident investigations, employee suggestions, and improvement in technology are utilized to update the safety aspects of the processes.

4.6  Compliance Audit

The City of Alexandria Adams Station performs periodic (at least every three years) audits of covered processes to verify the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP rule.  A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit, and any deficiencies noted by the audit are corrected in a timely manner.

4.7  Incident Investigations

The City of Alexandria Adams Station investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  The City of Alexandria Adams Station trains employees to identify and report any and all incidents requiring investigation.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the incident are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

4.8  Chemical-specific Prevention Steps - Chlorine

Industry standards are followed at The City of Alexandria Adams Station to help ensure the safe handling of chlorine.  The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation(DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved 1 ton containers and 150-lb cylinders.  The process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to guidelines required by The City of Alexandria Adams Station.

5.0  Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents or releases involving chlorine at The City of Alexandria Adams Station.

4.1  Safety Information

The City of Alexandria Adams Station maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of The City of Alexandria Adams Station processes.  Safety Data Sheets (SDS) document the physical and chemical properties of the hazardous substances handled at The City of Alexandria Adams Station, including the Chlorine in the covered process.  The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment in each covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards.

4.2  Hazard Review

The City of Alexandria Adams Station performs and periodically updates hazard reviews of the covered processes to help identify and control process hazards.  Checklists are used to guide the hazard review.  These checklists include items to help ensure The City of Alexandria Adams Station operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards, and regulations.

4.3  Operating Procedures

The City of Alexandria Adams Station develops and maintains operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to:

1. train employees and contractors, and
2. serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during normal and abnormal process conditions.

4.4  Training

The City of Alexandria Adams Station trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks.  A record of all training is maintained to help ensure new and refresher training is provided on a timely basis.

2.0  Description of The City of Alexandria  Adams Station and Regulated Substances

The City of Alexandria Adams Station handles one substance regulated by the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule in quantities above the Threshold Quantity.

Chlorine - stored in 1 ton containers and 150-lb cylinders for distribution to the drinking water chlorination sites.

3.0  Hazard Assessment

The RMP Rule requires The City of Alexandria Adams Station to perform a Hazard Assessment of the regulated substances stored and used in the covered processes at the facility.  The Hazard Assessment includes an offsite consequence analysis for the following scenarios:

Two worst-case (1-ton container and 150-lb cylinder) and Two alternative (1-ton container and 150-lb cylinder) release scenario for the toxic substance chlorine for the chlorination process unit at the facility.

The City of Alexandria Adams Station completed a Hazard Assessment for the covered processes and the results have been appropriately communicated to the local emergency response agencies.  The Hazard Assessment has been updated for the current RMP Re-Submission (January 2019).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The City of Alexandria Adams Station is located at 3460 Horseshoe Drive, Alexandria, LA.   Adams Station is a centralized storage location for the 1-ton chlorine containers and 150-lb Chlorine cylinders.  Chlorine containers and cylinders are shipped to the City of Alexandria's drinking water chlorination sites from the Adams Station.  A maximum of 31,500 pounds of chlorine are stored in one-ton containers and 150-lb cylinders.  The City of Alexandria Adams Station is included in written community emergency response plan.  In case of a chlorine leak, the City of Alexandria has an emergency response policy which requires City personnel to notify LA State Police Hazmat by calling the 911 center as well as local fire and police departments.  These emergency personnel are used to assist in evacuating citizens in the affected area.  Currently, the ity uses daily inspection, leak detection and a comprehensive preventative maintenance program to ensure the system is operating properly.  Plant personnel have been properly trained to handle chlorine stored in one-ton containers and 150-lb cylinders.  Formal and on-the-job training ensures plant personnel have the necessary knowledge and skill to properly maintain the chlorination system.  On-going operator training and preventive maintenance continue to be key tools to ensure the safety of the public.  The City of Alexandria Adams Station has no history of reportable release for chlorine.  There have been no injury or property loss associated with this chemical at this site.
